text:
(1)

385-387, 387½ Bleecker Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Perry Street. These frame houses probably date back to the time when this was the corner of George and Ogden Streets, 1803 or earlier. In 1811 Perry Street was known as Henry Street, but took its present name two years later. George Street did not become part of Bleecker Street until or after 1829.
September 26, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, three and a half years later. The frame houses have had a new coat of paint, and the shutters have been taken off. Within another two years, these old houses will have been taken down and rebuilt in white stucco.
February, 1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(1)

385-387, 387½ Bleecker Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Perry Street. These frame houses probably date back to the time when this was the corner of George and Ogden Streets, 1803 or earlier. In 1811 Perry Street was known as Henry Street, but took its present name two years later. George Street did not become part of Bleecker Street until or after 1829.
September 26, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, three and a half years later. The frame houses have had a new coat of paint, and the shutters have been taken off. Within another two years, these old houses will have been taken down and rebuilt in white stucco.
February, 1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

93 Perry Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Bleecker Street. This was an old three-story frame house which has recently been remodelled into the Spanish disguise shown here.
1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(1)
Thanksgiving Ragamuffins, 1933, No. 16. Some of the group shown in No. 15, standing in front of the grocery store at 383 Bleecker Street, on the S.E. corner of Perry Street.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 17. Another pair, in the same location.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 18. The same location. This boy is wearing one of the Mickey Mouse costumes created by Walt Disney Enterprises, Incorporated. "Mickey Mouse" is one of the most popular and successful animated cartoon creatures originated in the early 1920's by Walt Disney, and will possibly succeed in winning a permanent place in the juvenile pantheon. At the time of this picture Mickey was already becoming internationally known, in France as Michel Souris, for instance, and in the Spanish-speaking word as Miguel Ratoncito.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Thanksgiving ragamuffins, No.16-18.

text:
(1)
Thanksgiving Ragamuffins, 1933, No. 19. Two girls in black dominoes, on Bleecker Street.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 20. The same two in front of 381 Bleecker Street, adjoining the northeastern corner of Perry Street.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 21. At the same corner: two hard-boiled little golddiggers. One or both of them may be boys.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Thanksgiving ragamuffins, No.19-21.

text:
85 and 83 Perry Street, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Bleecker Street. The 3-story white structure that is partially shown on the left is No. 87 Perry Street and is at the N.E. corner directly. It is a frame constructed building with a stucco coat and also bears No. 385 on Bleecker Street.

August 3, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Perry Street, north side, at Bleecker Street and eastward, showing at the N.W. and N.E. corners respectively, Nos. 93-91 and 87. These structures have Bleecker Street numbers, which are 386 and 385.

August 3, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Perry Street, north side, west from Bleecker to Washington Streets, Note the Ninth Ave. Elevated Line on Greenwich Street.

August 3, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
